FUJI (headquarters in Chiryu City), which manufactures and sells electronic component mounting robots and industrial machinery, has taken on the development of a system to prevent "abandonment" such as leaving a child in a car.
A system that attaches a motion sensor to the inside of a car and sends a notification to the phone or chat when it detects movement.
The app is now being tested in Sweden.
Even if there are accidents that cause pain, we will protect the safety of children.
Currently, we are conducting a trial run with two vehicles for our after-school English program for children, "teracoya THANK (テラコヤ サンク)" in Chiryu City.

Motion sensors that detect the level of ambient human movement based on the temperature difference between the human body and the surrounding environment are installed in three locations on the ceiling of the vehicle.
When it detects no human presence for a given amount of time, it automatically shuts off.
By linking the state and information of the engine and doors, it can prevent misjudgments as much as possible.
The warning notification is sent through the cloud.
You can either call the number you registered beforehand or display it on your computer or smartphone chat.
It is not possible to register at multiple addresses.

I self-published my 10th book with the title "Dear Prime Minister, a 'Breakwater of Life' from Tōjinbō".
It has been picked up by newspapers all over the country, and we have received many letters from readers.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share with you the content of the interviews with the people who attempted suicide, and to create a "society where people can live comfortably" by addressing the "social and structural" environmental problems that are the causes of suicide in Japan.

We have been patrolling the waterfront of Tōjinbō in Fukui Prefecture, which is known as a suicide spot, for 18 years and 10 months, in order to prevent suicide. We continue to support those who are attempting suicide by discovering and protecting them, and helping them to start again.

This book is a compilation of the problems that have been reported by 784 people (as of February 6) that have been protected so far, and as a request to the Prime Minister of the Cabinet, it lists the following seven items that are necessary for the country to prevent suicide.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life-saving" activities.
(2) There are a lot more human rights issues in Inner Mongolia waiting to be raised.
(3) Suicides are victims of social and structural organized crime.
(4) The administrative organs treat the citizens living outside the jurisdiction as "strangers" and neglect them.
(5) Mental illness patients such as depression are drugged and commit suicide, but they are treated as "accidents".
6) The "duty of care" in suicide hotspots is being forgotten as commercialism takes over.

(7) The part of the doctrine of new religious groups that cannot be scientifically proven is a fraud, and the act of threatening to curse them in the future and offering them money in exchange for gold is blackmail.
It is necessary to publicly denounce and exclude the religious organization that commits this "fraud and extortion crime".

Toba City to double child-rearing allowance payments, seeks refund - Ise Newspaper

【Toba】Toba City announced on the 10th that there were 60,000 yen of mistaken payments to 12 people in 11 families in the child-rearing household living support special allowance (other household allowance) for the fiscal year of Reiwa 3.
The City said it is seeking compensation for the overpayment.
According to the city, it was discovered on January 27, 2020, when the guardian of a child who had previously received benefits pointed out the discrepancy.
It was confirmed that out of 79 households and 182 people who were eligible for the benefit in the same year, 12 households and 11 people received the benefit twice on July 20, 2020.
The city will pay 50,000 yen per child to households with children under high school age who are not subject to resident tax.

It is said that the data provided by the computer company that was commissioned to extract the target children from the data was mistakenly added to the data by a staff member who thought that high school students were not included, and that they were paid twice.
The person in charge of the childcare support room said, "We will take this situation seriously and make every effort to prevent a recurrence, such as rechecking the data."

Introduction to the forefather of plant research, and the collection of materials from Mount Hayachine. Exhibition planned by the city's comprehensive cultural property center. [Hanamaki] | Iwanichi Online Iwate Nippo Newspaper Co., Ltd.

The exhibition "People who introduced the flowers of Hayachine Peak - A brief history of the study of the plants of Hayachine Peak" that takes up the pioneers who built the foundation of the study of the plants of Hayachine Peak, which is known as a treasure trove of alpine plants, is being held at the city's comprehensive cultural property center in Ohasama, Hanamaki, until the 12th.

He has collected 124 valuable materials, including specimens collected by his predecessors, and introduced the footprints of his predecessors who were involved in the study of plants on Mount Hayachine.

The study of plants on Mount Hayachine began with the arrival of Russian plant researcher Karl Ivanovich Maximowicz (1827-91) in the late Edo period, and with the collection of plants under Maximowicz's guidance by Sugawa Chonosuke (1842-1925), who was born in Shibamatsu.

Maximo Vitch, who was not allowed to freely walk around the country for foreigners, asked for an interview with the Asakawa family and continued his research for three years with Yokohama and Nagasaki as his base.

After returning to Japan, Maximo supported the research, and the discovery of the "Himekozakura", "Nambotouuchi-sou", and "Miyamayamabuki-shouma" plants native to Mount Hayachine led to the announcement of the discovery.

After that, the modern plant taxonomist Makino Tomitaro (1862-1957) published "Bistorta hayachinensis", "Cerastium kawakamii", "Draba japonica", and "Arenaria katoana" in 1903 (Meiji 36) based on the local collection of researchers, and in 1905 (Meiji 38) he climbed early Takadakeyama and discovered and
From the exhibition materials, it is clear that many researchers have revealed the precious alpine plants.

Also introduced are Shoyama Matsuzo (1874-1948), who studied botany while serving as principal of Hakamachi Elementary School and participated in the survey for the preservation of natural monuments in 1927 (Showa 2), and Yokawa Nanoru (1914-1988), who was a curator at the Yokawa Museum in Ohasama and participated in the publication of "Sakidake Plants".

"Each plant in Mount Hayachine has a name with a lot of research and connections with people behind it. It can connect researchers from all over the country," says Yoshida Shunpei, a researcher at the same center.

The exhibition is composed of four chapters, and in the first chapter, the faith and history of Mount Hayachine are introduced, and in the second chapter, the geological features of Mount Hayachine are introduced based on the research of German geologist Heinrich Edmund Naumann (1854-1927), who laid the foundation of Japanese geology.
